Supported metal catalysts frequently experience diminished catalytic activity, attributed to the loss of active sites and impaired electron transport efficiency during reactions. From the perspective of structure-activity relationships, developing composite multivalent metal catalysts and elucidating the key role of synergistic effects are crucial for enhancing electron transport and ultimately improving oxidative desulfurization(ODS) performance. In this study, core-shell nanostructure based on Phosphomolybdic acid(HPM) and amino-functionalized MIL-101(Fe)(NH2−MIL-101(Fe)) was successfully synthesized through a facile and controllable impregnation method. The phosphate groups in HPM not only regulate the acidity of the catalytic environment but also maintain the overall structural stability. The enhanced mobility of lattice oxygen in HPM promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies during its interaction with NH2−MIL-101(Fe). The abundance of directional anchor sites for HPM can be provided by coordination via empty orbitals in Mo-O clusters with lone pairs of electrons on the nitrogen atoms in the amino group of NH2−MIL-101(Fe). The variable valence states of Fe and Mo efficiently activate hydrogen peroxide(H2O2). Furthermore, the mass transfer can be facilitated by carefully design pore windows, which matching the size of sulfur compounds. These synergistic effects collectively achieved 99.8 % ODS performance under optimal conditions(V(Ionic liquids, ILs)=1 mL, V(H2O2)=0.15 mL, catalyst: model oil (0.02:5, g/mL), 50 °C), while also demonstrating excellent recyclability. The reaction activation energy (45.25 kJ/mol) is calculated and the dual-pathway synergistic catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed by experiment and characterization. This study provides a promising design strategy for the research of advanced functional catalysts. Graphical abstract Nanoporous composite materials in efficient oxidation desulfurization system Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative desulfurization Synergistic effect Core-shell structure Electron channel Oxygen vacancy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Recent regulatory developments have witnessed global governing bodies and environmental agencies progressively implementing stringent fuel quality specifications, with particular emphasis on reducing sulfur content to ultralow levels (≤10 parts per million, ppm) [1]. To address this challenge, countries have actively carried out research on fuel desulfurization technologies. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is widely used in industrial desulfurization processes. However, for aromatic sulfur compounds such as benzothiophene (BT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), and their derivatives, HDS requires harsh conditions, including high temperatures and high pressures [2,3]. Additionally, HDS encounters obstacles such as high equipment costs and safety risks, making it difficult to meet current stringent sulfur content standards. Thus, developing new desulfurization technologies that operate under milder conditions and achieve deep sulfur removal is of significant research and practical value. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) technology has become a research focus due to its efficient removal of sulfur compounds and mild reaction conditions using oxidants like hydrogen peroxide(H2O2) [4,5]. In some of the previous studies, aromatic sulfur compounds are gradually oxidized to sulfoxides and sulfones by an excited state generated from hydrogen peroxide [6]. A variety of catalytically active materials have been investigated [7]. Heteropoly acids (HPAs) with Keggin structures exhibit exceptional catalytic performance due to their distinctive redox properties and pronounced Brønsted acidity [8–10]. Within this category of compounds, phosphomolybdic acid (HPM) stands out due to its phosphated core structure, which not only preserves the comprehensive molecular integrity but also modulates the environmental acidity. The presence of molybdenum atoms, serving as active sites for oxygen removal, renders HPM a highly promising candidate for ODS [11]. However, HPM face several challenges in practical applications, such as leaching due to high solubility in polar solvents, limited surface area restricting catalytic activity, and insufficient thermal stability [12–15]. To address these issues, researchers have proposed various strategies, including loading HPM onto nanoporous supports [16], preparing HPM-based ionic liquids [17], and developing HPM-based composites [18]. Nevertheless, there remains significant prospect for further optimization from the perspective of structure-activity relationships, specifically by enhancing the dispersion of active sites and improving electron transport efficiency. In light of these challenges, the development of novel nanoporous materials to overcome these bottlenecks is of paramount importance. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of nanoporous materials, have garnered significant attention due to their highly tunable structures, large specific surface areas, and abundant functional sites. They are applied in various fields, including catalytic oxidation [19], gas and liquid storage [20,21], separation adsorption [22], photocatalysis [23,24], electrocatalysis [25], and pharmaceuticals [26], etc. Fe-based MIL (from Institut Lavoisier) are an attractive class of MOFs. Iron is inexpensive, widely available, magnetic, and easy to recycle. Its variable valency facilitates electron transport, activating sulfur compounds and fostering the conversion of hydrogen peroxide to an excited state. The distinctive cage-like structure imparts an exceptionally high specific surface area and remarkable chemical stability. However, the surface of unmodified MIL lacks sufficient reactive sites, leading to several drawbacks when using pure MIL for ODS. These include slow reaction rates, high activation energy, incomplete desulfurization effect, and insufficiently mild reaction conditions. To improve the ODS performance of MIL, a promising strategy involves the introduction of appropriate functional groups to fully exploit synergistic catalytic effects. The integration of HPM with Fe-based MIL presents a viable approach for constructing composite catalytic materials, potentially facilitating the establishment of efficient nanoscale electron transport pathways and improving the dispersion of active sites. This work aims to design a promising composite catalyst by incorporating HPM into the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) structure, creating an efficient and recyclable ODS catalytic system. The catalytic oxidation of sulfide using amino-functionalized Fe-MIL embedded with Keggin-structured phosphomolybdic acid has not been systematically explored in the field of ODS. Therefore, this research focused on the structure-activity relationship through a facile and controllable impregnation method to control component ratios. This approach enables the design of a core-shell structure with optimized pore window sizes, ensuring full contact between sulfide compounds and active sites [27]. Phosphate groups enhance catalytic activity by regulating the acidity of the catalytic environment, thereby fulfilling the fundamental requirements of acid-catalyzed systems. As crucial components of catalyst bonding, these groups contribute significantly to durability and structural stability. Moreover, the mobility of lattice oxygen in HPM facilitates the formation of oxygen vacancies when interacting with NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). This process results in trapped electrons within these vacancies. The coordination between the empty orbitals in the Mo-O clusters of HPM and lone-pair electrons in the amino groups of the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was facilitated. This provided abundant directional anchoring sites for HPM, significantly enhancing its dispersion and preventing leaching. According to molecular orbital theory, HPM may interact with the electron pairs of nitrogen atoms through d-π conjugation, and electrons trapped in the oxygen vacancy state are easily excited. This unique structural design establishes a highly efficient electron transport channel that further enhances the valence changing properties of the active site. The variable valence states of Fe and Mo in the catalyst efficiently activate hydrogen peroxide, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. The HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst ingeniously combines the exceptional catalytic activity of HPM with the structural advantages of MOFs, achieving a synergistic effect where “1 + 1 > 2″, effectively overcoming the limitations of traditional HPM catalysts. This innovative design offers a promising solution for advancing deep desulfurization technology in fuels and presents novel approaches in the field of advanced functional catalytic materials. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents Anhydrous iron(III) chloride (FeCl3, 98 %), 2-Aminoterephthalic acid (NH2-DBC, 98 %), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 98 %), Phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (HPM, 98 %), 1-Benzothiophene (BT, 98 %), Dibenzothiophene (DBT, 99 %), and 4,6-Dimethyl-dibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT, 98 %), N-octane (98 %), Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 %), 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ( [BMIM]BF4, 97 %), Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 99 %), Ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA, 98 %), Ethanol (EtOH, 99 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical ReagentCo., Ltd. Deionized water was used throughout all experiments. 2.2 Syntheses of NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was successfully synthesized according to the reported method with slight adjustments [28]. Anhydrous FeCl3 (0.3245 g, 0.002 mol), NH2-DBC (0.1812 g, 0.001 mol) and DMF (40 mL) were added to a 100 mL beaker for stirring until complete dissolution, and the solution was subsequently transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-line autoclave and reacted for 20 h at 110 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the brownish-yellow reaction precipitate product was obtained by centrifugation from solution, which was washed multiple times with EtOH and DMF in order to extract impurities and unreacted materials, as well as to ensure that the entrapped DMF molecules have been successfully eliminated. Finally, the product was dried at 60 °C under normal pressure for 12 h to obtain NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). 2.3 Preparation of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) The synthesis of the HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst involved combining the prepared NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and HPM in a round-bottom flask with 15 mL of ethanol. Using the impregnation method, the mixture was vigorously stirred for 24 h in 50 °C. The resulting brownish-yellow solid was obtained through centrifugation and washed several times with ethanol and deionized water. After drying overnight at 60 °C, the final HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst was produced. Various catalysts with different active component ratios were prepared using mass ratios of xHPM@yNH2 −MIL-101(Fe) (x:y = 5:5, 6:4, 7:3, 8:2). 2.4 Characterization instruments and methods All samples discussed in this study were analyzed using diverse characterization techniques. The valence states of the samples were analysed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the experiments were carried out using an XPS system equipped with an Al-Kα radiation source (Thermo Scientific K-Alpha). An Agilent 8860 gas chromatograph (GC) was used to detect the sulfur content in the model oil. Please refer to the Supporting Information for detailed characterization. 2.5 ODS experiments Pre-prepared model oil was utilized in the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process. A specific amount of sulfur-containing compound (DBT, BT, 4,6-DMDBT) was introduced to pure n-octane and dissolved utilizing ultrasound to create a standard model oil with 500 parts per million (ppm) sulfur content. For experimental analysis, model oil (5 mL) was used as the test sample, with the addition of catalyst, extractant( [BMIM]BF4), and oxidant(H2O2) into a 50 mL three-necked flask to establish the ODS reaction system. The loading ratio of catalysts, the quantities of composite catalysts, extractants, oxidants, and reaction temperature were inverstigated in this study. In addition, the desulfurization rate of various sulfur compounds and the recyclability were studied under optimal conditions. The desulfurization rate of the model oil was analyzed using gas chromatography (GC). (1) Desulfurization rate ( % ) = ( C 0 − C t ) / C 0 × 100 % where C0 (500 ppm) is the initial sulfur content in the model oil, and Ct (ppm) is the real-time sulfur content during the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts As seen in Scheme 1 , the catalyst was synthesized through a two-step process. First, NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was prepared via solvothermal method. Subsequently, phosphomolybdic acid (HPM) was loaded into its structure via an impregnation technique to obtain the ultimate catalyst. The presence of empty orbitals in the Mo-O clusters of HPM, along with the lone-pair electrons on the nitrogen atoms in the amino groups of the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe), which facilitates coordination. This interaction provides abundant directional anchoring sites for HPM, significantly enhancing its dispersion. The variable valency of iron and molybdenum in the catalyst efficiently activates hydrogen peroxide. The phosphate group can effectively regulate and maintain the acidic environment of the reaction system. This acidic environment promotes H2O2 heterocleavage to generate highly reactive •OH radicals. These synergistic effects together achieve excellent ODS efficiency. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was employed to elucidate the crystal structure of the synthesized catalyst(Fig. 1 a). The XRD pattern exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 16.4°, 17.8°, and 18.7°, which can be assigned to the (103), (200) and (201) of the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) phase [29,30]. The crystal structure of HPM was also verified(Fig. S1). Catalyst with varying HPM loading ratios exhibited high consistency in their peak profiles after immobilization of HPM. Notably, the XRD patterns of the HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) samples lacked distinct peaks attributable to HPM, indicating a uniform dispersion of HPM within the frameworks. The observed attenuation in diffraction peak intensity of the synthesized catalyst may be attributed to the introduction of phosphate groups from HPM. These groups regulate the acidity of the catalytic environment, potentially inducing the formation of additional defects. This phenomenon was further corroborated by subsequent XPS analysis. These results provide compelling evidence for the effective encapsulation of HPM within the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). In order to verify the formation of catalysts, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were employed to characterize NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) as well as HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalysts with varying HPM loading ratios (Fig. 1b). For NH2 −MIL-101(Fe), a broader peak is observed at 3373.5 cm-1, which is mainly attributed to a combination of asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the amino group [31,32]. The peaks at 1256.3 cm-1 and 1584.7 cm-1 correspond to the CN stretching vibration of the amino group and the C = O asymmetric stretching vibration of the carboxylic acid moiety in NH2-DBC [31]. Moreover, all the synthesized catalysts exhibit similar spectral features. For HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(6:4), 1060.5 cm-1, 960.7 cm-1, 879.1 cm-1, and 805.6 cm-1 are the characteristic vibrational peaks of HPM with Keggin structure, which are corresponding to P-Oa, Mo=Od, Mo-Ob −Mo, and Mo-Oc −Mo, respectively [33]. Corresponding characteristic peaks appear in the remaining ratios, suggesting that the Keggin structure of HPM was preserved in the synthesized catalysts. 1645.9 cm-1, 1417.5 cm-1 and 1384.8 cm-1 are attributed to the NH scissoring vibrations, symmetric and asymmetric vibration of the OH group, respectively [31]. The presence of the above characteristic peaks confirms the successful synthesis of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were employed to characterize the morphology and composition of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 , the microstructure and morphology of NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) can be obtained using SEM images. Uniform cubic octahedral morphology was predominantly observed [34,35]. In addition, the uniform distribution of molybdenum (Mo) and phosphorus (P) elements within the composite catalyst was evidenced by the EDX elemental mapping (Fig. 3 ). The homogeneous immobilization of HPM on NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) is indirectly corroborated by this distribution pattern. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and HR-TEM micrographs of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) were shown in Fig. 4 . The characteristic octahedral morphology and rich pore structure of the catalyst are further corroborated by TEM images, while HR-TEM analysis reveals a lattice spacing of 0.219 nm in HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). These findings provide compelling evidence for the successful formation of a dispersed anchoring structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the elemental composition and chemical states of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) in detail. XPS survey scan revealed that the primary elements in the catalysts include C, N, O, Mo, Fe and P (Fig. 5 a). Additionally, detailed spectrum analysis of individual elements furnished a more comprehensive comprehension of their chemical states and facilitated semi-quantitative calculations. Typically, the C 1 s peak comprises overlapping contributions from sp³ hybridized CC (284.8 eV) and CN (286.5 eV) bonds, as well as sp² hybridized C = C bonds (288.9 eV)(Fig. 5b), corresponding to the carbon components of NH2-DBC, organic para-carboxyl groups, and amino functional groups, respectively [36]. Compared to organic structures without amino groups [31], the C = C bond exhibited a 0.2 eV shift to a lower binding energy. This phenomenon can be attributed to the incorporated amino group acting as an electron-donating moiety, facilitating electron transfer and subsequently increasing the electron density of the corresponding carbon atoms. The O 1 s spectrum of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(Fig. 5c) exhibits peaks at 530.5 eV, 531.1 eV, and 532.1 eV, which can be assigned to Fe-O bonds (lattice oxygen), C = O bonds, and OH bonds, respectively [19,37]. The binding energy of lattice oxygen is shifted to a higher position due to the amino group enhancing electron transport from the ligand to the center of the metal. Notably, the characteristic binding energy peak at 532.9 eV in the O 1 s region corresponds to the oxygen vacancies. Previous investigations have indicated that the presence of these oxygen vacancies contributes to enhanced catalytic efficiency [38]. In the N 1 s region(Fig. 5d), the peaks at 398.8 eV and 400 eV can be attributed to NH and CN bonds, respectively [39]. Effective integration of the peak areas revealed 1:2 ratio, corresponding to the stoichiometric ratio of N to H atoms in the amino group. The peaks at 233.4 eV and 236.9 eV can be attributed to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 of Mo(VI)(Fig. 5e), respectively [40]. In addition, Mo(V) peaks for Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 appear at lower binding energies of 232.3 eV and 235.4 eV, respectively. In addition, we calculated the ratio of the valence states of the Mo (V / VI = 25.4 %). In contrast to pure HPM, where Mo exists entirely in the Mo(VI) state, the synthesized HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst exhibits partial reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(V), indicating electron transport [33,41]. This evidence suggests that the interaction between HPM and NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) is not a simple mechanical mixture but involves chemical interactions. Therefore, it was confirmed that the amino group in NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) successfully targeted the anchoring of HPM. Concurrently, Mo(V) in the reduced state can facilitate the activation of the oxidant, which is conducive to the enhancement of the ODS catalytic performance of the catalyst [33,42]. In the Fe 2p spectrum of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(Fig. 5f), the peaks at 712.6 eV and 726.4 eV can be attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbital splitting of Fe(III) [37], while the Fe(II) 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks are located at 711.2 eV and 724.9 eV, respectively. The broadening of the peak shape is attributed to the presence of shake-up satellite peaks. These peaks are characterized by a combination of Fe(II) and Fe(III) valence states at high binding energy positions. Additionally, the ratio of the two Fe oxidation states in the synthesized catalyst is (II / III = 86.7 %). Previous studies have demonstrated that Fe(II) species facilitate electron transport within the catalyst, enhancing the decomposition of H2O2 into more potent oxidative radicals [31]. The nanoporous properties of catalysts, particularly their compatibility with sulfide molecular dimensions in the oil phase, are critical for optimizing mass transfer processes that govern ODS efficiency [27]. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) were measured at 77.35 K. As depicted in Fig. 6b, the pore size distribution of the catalyst depicted shows primary pore sizes of 2.05 nm and 3.88 nm, indicating the formation of a hierarchical nanoporous structure. A clear hysteresis loop is observed within the relative pressure range of 0.4–1.0, characteristic of type IV isotherms, indicating that the synthesized material possesses a mesoporous structure [43]. The BET surface area of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was 159.3191 m²/g. Additionally, the BJH desorption pore volume and average pore diameter are 0.159 cm³/g and 10.74 nm, respectively, with consistent pore size distribution evident from the distribution curves. HPM are precisely anchored on both the external surface and internal structure, leading to a dispersed distribution. Excessive HPM may partially obstruct the mesopores and cavities of NH2 −MIL-101(Fe), potentially reducing mass transfer efficiency in the reaction system. Consequently, precise impregnation method was employed to maintain optimal pore structure and specific surface area. By optimizing the composite ratio, active sites were maximized within the nanoporous framework, ultimately enhancing the ODS catalytic performance. The thermal decomposition behavior of the catalyst was examined in a nitrogen atmosphere. As illustrated in Fig. 6c, the gradual mass loss observed in HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) can be attributed to the removal of adsorbed water molecules. For comparison, TGA-DSC analyses of HPM (Fig. S2) and NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) (Fig. S3) were also conducted. Among the three samples (Fig. 6d), the synthesized HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst exhibited the highest thermal stability, as evidenced by the lowest mass loss. This enhanced stability can be ascribed to the formation of new chemical bonds and a more stable chemical composition. Consequently, the catalyst demonstrated sufficient stability for subsequent ODS processes. 3.2 ODS performance evaluation of catalysts 3.2.1 Optimization of reaction conditions In order to compare the composite ratio of HPM and NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) for ODS performance, the catalytic properties at different mass ratios (5:5, 6:4, 7:3, 8:2) was systematically investigated in this study(Fig. 7 a). The desulfurization rate was increased from 80.2 % for HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(8:2) to 90.4 % for HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(7:3) along with increasing the proportion of NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) under the same conditions in 180 min. Notably, the desulfurization rate was further increased to 98.1 % using HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(6:4), demonstrating potential for deep desulfurization. However, further increase in the ratio of NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) resulted in a decrease in the desulfurization rate of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(5:5) to 70.5 %. This decrease is attributed to insufficient HPM loading leads to a lack of catalytic active sites and incomplete construction of electron transport channels. These results suggest that the realization of the synergistic effect needs to be precisely regulated. Pore clogging can be induced by excessive HPM loading. The component ratios were precisely controlled using an impregnation method, which enabled the construction of an optimal pore structure while maintaining the excellent performance. This approach facilitated effective interaction with target sulfide molecules. The optimal mass ratio of HPM to NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) is 6:4, where the composite exhibits superior catalytic performance. Based on the above results, HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(6:4) was selected as the optimal catalyst for subsequent study. In this study, the catalyst amount, reaction temperature, the volume of H2O2, the volume of ILs( [BMIM]BF4) were adjusted to determine the optimal conditions for HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) in the ODS process. The impact of varying catalyst dosages (0.01–0.04 g) on a prepared 500 ppm model oil were studied at a reaction temperature of 50 °C, with ILs(1 mL) and H2O2(0.10 mL)(Fig. S4). The desulfurization efficiency was improved significantly with increasing catalyst dosage. Using 0.01 g of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe), a desulfurization rate of 85.5 % was achieved after 180 min. Upon increasing the dosage to 0.02 g, a desulfurization efficiency of 98.1 % was achieved. The dosage was increased from 0.03 g to 0.04 g, which accelerated the reaction rate. However, the enhancements were not substantial. From the perspective of economy in practical application, 0.02 g was selected as the optimal catalyst dosage. The reaction temperature critically governs both kinetic and thermodynamic parameters in ODS, thereby dictating the overall catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 7b, the ODS reaction rate was relatively slow and the desulfurization rate was only 70.3 % at 30 °C after 180 min. As the temperature gradually increased, the desulfurization efficiency improved significantly: reaching 88.4 % at 40 °C and further increasing to 98.1 % at 50 °C, respectively. This trend indicates that higher temperatures enhance the thermal motion of reactants, which promotes mass transfer processes and accelerates the oxidative conversion of thiophene to sulfones. With further temperature elevation, the reaction rate initially accelerates. However, a significant deceleration in the desulfurization rate is observed after 100 min, indicating a performance bottleneck. This threshold behavior originates from the accelerated H2O2 decomposition under thermal stress, which induces catalyst agglomeration and active site deactivation [44]. As shown in Fig. 7c, this study investigated the effect of H2O2vol on the performance of ODS. The results showed that the conversion efficiency of DBT were close to each other and both exceed 97.5 % when the H2O2vol was 0.05 mL and 0.10 mL, respectively. When the H2O2vol was increased to 0.15 mL, the conversion efficiency of DBT was significantly improved and achieved 99.8 % deep desulfurization. However, the conversion efficiency of DBT decreased when the volume of H2O2 was further increased. Theoretically, the catalytic reaction efficiency should increase with higher concentrations of oxidant, but in the actual reaction system, the excess H2O2 acts as a free radical scavenger, see eq. (2)-(3) [45]. Based on these results, the optimum amount of H2O2 added was determined to be 0.15 mL in this study. (2) H 2 O 2 + ( ⋅ OH ) → HO 2 ⋅ + H 2 O (3) HO 2 ⋅ + ( ⋅ OH ) → O 2 + H 2 O ILs( [BMIM]BF4) plays an important role in the ODS reaction process by extracting sulfur compounds from the oil phase and facilitating the reaction. In this study, the effect of different ILs volume on the performance of ODS was investigated (50 °C, H2O2(0.15 mL), HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe)(0.02g ))(Fig. S5). In the system with only catalyst and oxidant, there was almost no desulfurization effect due to the lack of carrier for mass transfer medium of sulfide in the oil phase (analysis of the phenomenon is described below). With the addition of 0.5 mL of ILs as the extractant, the reaction rate was significantly increased to 95.1 %. When the volume of ILs was increased to 1 mL, the sulfide was almost completely oxidized and the desulfurization rate reached 99.8 %. However, excess ILs did not enhance the reaction rate significantly, and there was a weak decline in the depth of desulfurization instead. This may be attributed to the fact that the excess extractant increased the reaction space, resulting in a lower chance of effective collision between the reactants. Therefore, the appropriate volume of ILs should be combined with catalysts and oxidants to achieve the optimal reaction performance. 3.2.2 Desulfurization properties of different sulfides Given the complex composition of practical fuels extending beyond DBT, we systematically evaluated the HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst's versatility through comparative ODS studies of BT and 4,6-DMDBT (Fig. 7d). Under optimal conditions, the desulfurization rates of DBT, 4,6-DMDBT and BT reached 99.8 %, 77.5 % and 31.7 % in 180 min, respectively. Consequently, the desulfurization performance of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) for these three sulfur compounds was ranked as DBT > 4,6-DMDBT > BT. According to previous studies, the electron density of the S atom is an important parameter for describing the reactivity of ODS. The electron densities of S atoms for BT, DBT and 4,6-DMDBT were 5.739, 5.758 and 5.760, respectively [46]. In general, the higher the electron density of sulphur atoms, the more easily attacked during the oxidation process, thus showing a higher reactivity [19]. Nevertheless, factors such as the steric hindrance and catalyst characteristics also significantly affected the desulfurization performance. The substantial steric hindrance due to the methyl group in the 4,6-DMDBT molecule results in a reduction of ODS performance. Considering that HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) possesses a fixed window pore size structure, the molecular radius of the three sulfides were BT (6.51 Å), DBT (7.86 Å) and 4,6-DMDBT (7.86 Å) [47], which were able to match the catalyst pore sizes derived from BET. These results highlight the importance of optimizing window sizes to match target molecules when designing nanoporous core-shell structure catalysts [27]. 3.2.3 ODS reaction kinetics analysis Investigating the reaction kinetics and apparent activation energy of ODS is a scientific and intuitive systematic study, which is of great value for the analysis of the practical application of ODS and the elaboration of its mechanism [48]. Consequently, the ODS kinetic performance of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was further investigated under optimal conditions for DBT, BT, and 4,6-DMDBT. Previous reports have demonstrated that the ODS reaction process follows pseudo-first-order kinetics [19,49]. (4) − d C t d t = k C t (5) ln C 0 C t = kt (6) t 1 / 2 = ln 2 k (7) lnk = − E a RT + lnA The desulfurization performance of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) for different sulfur-containing compounds under optimal conditions was illustrated in Fig. S6. The slope of the linear fit, obtained by plotting ln(C0/Ct) against time, represents the first-order reaction rate constant (k), with R2 as the correlation coefficient (Eq. (4) to Eq. (5)). The k-values for the three sulfur-containing compounds DBT, BT, and 4,6-DMDBT are 0.03754, 0.00146, and 0.00847 min-1, respectively, with corresponding R2 values of 0.97424, 0.95957, and 0.90368. The half-lives (t1/2) calculated using eq. (6) are 18.464, 474.758, and 81.836 min for DBT, BT, and 4,6-DMDBT, respectively. HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) exhibits superior kinetic characteristics for DBT desulfurization. Notably, DBT demonstrates the shortest half-life among the three sulfur compounds studied, corroborating the aforementioned analysis results. Subsequently, the apparent activation energy (Ea) of the ODS reaction was analyzed. First-order kinetic performance was fitted at different temperatures (303, 313, 323, 333 K), images were obtained with ln(1-X) as the vertical coordinate and time as the horizontal coordinate(Fig. 8 a), where X is the rate of conversion. The rate constants for HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyzed DBT desulfurization at 303, 313, 323, and 333 K were 0.00631, 0.011239, 0.02434, and 0.03042 min-1, respectively. An Arrhenius plot was constructed with (lnk) as the y-axis and (1/RT) as the x-axis, where the slope represents the apparent activation energy (Ea)(Eq. (7)). Consequently, the apparent activation energy for DBT desulfurization using HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was 45.25 kJ/mol(Fig. 8b). 3.2.4 Comparison of ODS performance under different reaction conditions To elucidate the structure-activity relationships of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe), we systematically optimized reaction parameters and evaluated its operational efficacy in ODS processes (Fig. 8c). The experimental results show that the desulfurization rate after 180 min is only 20.1 % when only an equal volume of H2O2 is added without any catalyst. Under the condition of keeping the temperature constant, we compared the effect of different pure substances as catalysts. At optimal H2O2 and ILs volume, pure NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) increased the desulfurization rate by only 9.0 % in 180 min, whereas HPM as the active center significantly increased the rate to 65.6 %. NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and HPM were added separately at the designed mass ratios to verify that synergistic action resulted in 55.3 % desulfurization. Evidently, the hybrid nanoarchitecture of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) demonstrates a synergistic integration of functional components, where the immobilized catalyst achieves enhanced catalytic performance through electronic modulation between the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and HPM species. Within 120 min, the desulfurization rate exceeded 90.0 %, ultimately achieving deep desulfurization. Notably, the synergistic integration of these two components not only overcame the individual desulfurization rate limitations, but also exhibited a superior catalytic effect, demonstrating a “1 + 1 > 2″ phenomenon. ILs have a key role in the ODS reaction system [50,51]. It was shown that in the absence of the ILs, even with optimal condition, the desulfurization performance was extremely poor. This phenomenon can be explained by the function of the ILs as an extractant, which extracts thiophene compounds from the oil phase into the ILs phase. Subsequently, these compounds undergo catalytic oxidation reactions with HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and H2O2 in the ILs phase (Specific mechanism is discussed below). Images of the reaction systems under different catalytic conditions were recorded(Fig. S7). In the catalytic system devoid of ILs, remarkable color alterations were observed. This was likely attributable to the insufficient reaction space, leading to the aggregation of H2O2 on the surface of catalyst and a structural transformation into molybdenum-peroxo complexes. It's worth highlighting that ILs serve dual roles as both extraction media and reaction promoters. They considerably boost the solubility and dispersion of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) in the extraction phase, thus enhancing the mass transfer efficiency of reactants within the system. In order to highlight the advantages of ILs, comparisons were made with other extractants (CH3CN, MeOH, DMF) (Fig. S8). The results showed that ILs occupy a significant advantage in terms of compatibility and safety. Moreover, a higher desulfurization rate of ILs can be obtained than other extractants. This dual functionality effectively overcomes the limitations typically associated with heterogeneous catalytic systems, providing a more favorable microenvironment for the reaction. A comparison of the ODS performance of the catalyst introduced in this study with previously developed catalysts was presented in Table S1. It requires less extractant and catalyst dosage while operating at milder temperatures. The lower activation energy (45.25 kJ/mol) suggests a more efficient reaction pathway. These factors, combined with its excellent stability and recyclability, make our catalyst a promising candidate for practical ODS applications. HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst, prepared via a facile and controllable impregnation method, achieved deep desulfurization with a little dosage of catalyst under mild conditions. 3.2.5 Regeneration and oxidation product The regeneration test is the most direct method to assess the renewability of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). Specifically, the catalyst is washed three times with ethanol and DMF after each reaction, then dried for 8 h. The recovered catalyst was used for the next round of ODS reaction. As demonstrated in Fig. 8d, the ODS performance of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was maintained at 96.6 % even after six cycles, indicating its excellent repeatability. In order to verify the stability of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) after the ODS reaction, the reused and fresh catalysts were characterized by XRD and XPS. XRD patterns of fresh and recycle HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) was presented in Fig. 9 a. The main diffraction peaks of recycle HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) were still present in the spectrum without any collapse of the framework structure, indicating good stability. The directional anchoring prevents leaching of active sites. The new diffraction peaks observed in the XRD pattern of recycled HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) are likely due to the deposition of oxidation byproducts on the catalyst surface. While these deposits do not cause a collapse of the framework structure, they may partially obstruct the active sites and weaken the adsorption properties of the catalyst for reactants. XPS analysis of the recycle catalyst further confirms that the overall multivalent system is retained (Fig. S9), and all characterization analyses can support the excellent regeneration ability of the catalyst in the ODS system. The GC real-time chromatogram of DBT under optimal conditions was demonstrated in Fig. S10. The characteristic peak of DBT at 9.89 min gradually decreases during the reaction, and the final desulfurization rate is calculated by integrating the area of the spectral peaks. To further verify the oxidation products in the ODS system, FT-IR analysis was conducted on the reaction products. After the reaction, the model oil and catalyst were separated, and the reaction products were extracted from the ILs phase using carbon tetrachloride(CCl4). The FT-IR spectrum of the reaction products were compared with those of both DBT(Fig. S11) and DBTO2(Fig. 9b). It was found that the peaks matched precisely with DBTO2. This confirms that DBTO2 is the final oxidation product of DBT in the ODS system. 3.2.6 The active radical of oxidative desulfurization process In order to further determine the possible oxidation mechanism of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) during ODS process, it is necessary to conduct a comprehensive investigation into the characteristic states of the catalyst and reactive radicals involved [52]. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was introduced to further examine the existence of oxygen vacancy. As illustrated in Fig. 9c, the bound single electron (VO+) of oxygen vacancy was confirmed by the paramagnetic signal with a g-value of 2.003. These trapped electrons migrate to NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) through the fast channel of electrons to realize the in-situ reduction of Fe(Ⅲ). This phenomenon was consistent with the XPS analysis, which provided the foundation for mechanistic studies. To investigate the role of reactive radicals in the ODS process, radical scavengers were introduced into the model oil. Specifically, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), effective scavengers for H + and •OH radicals respectively [53], were added to the reaction system. As illustrated in Fig. 9d, the addition of EDTA resulted in a desulfurization rate of 97.6 %, indicating that H + was not an active radical for HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) in the ODS process. Notably, the introduction of DMSO led to a sharp decrease in the desulfurization rate to 56.7 %, demonstrating that •OH was the primary active radical in the ODS process. •OH have significant electrophilic properties [54], they are the main oxidizing agents in ODS system. The dehydrating properties of DMSO inhibit the back-extraction of sulfides from the ILs phase into the oil phase by water. Additionally, the ability of DMSO to modulate acidity contributes to the observed partial desulfurization rates. Based on these findings, the reaction mechanism was elucidated. 3.2.7 Oxidative desulfurization mechanism The mechanism of HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) in ODS reaction was thoroughly investigated. The schematic diagram of the ODS reaction system was illustrated in Fig. S12. In this system, sulfur compounds from the model oil are initially extracted into the ILs phase followed by the oxidation reaction under milder temperature conditions in the presence of catalyst and H2O2. Due to their high polarity, sulfones are more easily extracted by the ILs phase, thus achieving in deep oxidative desulfurization. The specific ODS mechanism was shown in Fig. 10 . Based on previous reports and various characterization analyses, two synergistic reaction pathways are identified in the HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst. These pathways are centered on the valence state changes of Mo-O and Fe-O cluster, respectively, which serve as the active reaction centers. The construction of the first reaction pathway was attributed to the formation of strong electrostatic interactions between the amino group on NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and HPM, which led to the directional anchoring of HPM and the establishment of an efficient electron transport channel, thus improving the desulfurization performance of the catalyst. Specifically, electrons transport from the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) to the HPM component, inducing a partial reduction of Mo(VI) to Mo(V) in HPM. This electron transport mechanism was experimentally verified through XPS analysis. Interestingly, the formation of Mo(V) played a crucial role in enhancing catalytic activity, and Mo(Ⅴ) exhibited higher catalytic activity compared to Mo(Ⅵ) [33]. From the reaction mechanism point of view, it is postulated that the newly generated Mo(V) active sites on the catalyst surface interact with H2O2, facilitating the generation of reactive radicals. The second reaction pathway was established through Fe-O clusters. The detection of Fe(II) suggests that amino groups induced the in-situ formation of Fe(II) in the NH2 −MIL-101(Fe). This configuration creates favorable conditions for redox cycling half-reactions between Fe(III) and Fe(II), providing beneficial pathways for rapid electron transport. The specific process can be elucidated as follows(eq. (8)-(13)): H2O2 in the ILs phase reacts with the anchored deficient Mo(V)-O clusters, and electrons(e-) are transferred from the metal center Mo(V) to H2O2 to generate the main reactive substances •OH and -OH [55], and undergoes valence change Mo(Ⅴ → Ⅵ). The Fe-O clusters also exhibit the similar electron transport process. Fe(III) sites can adsorb the S atom of DBT and receive the e-, which leads to valence state transitions Fe(III → II), thereby activating the sulfide compounds. Subsequently, •OH radicals attack the S atom on the activated DBT, which results in the oxidative transformation from DBT to dibenzothiophene sulfoxide (DBTO). As the fast electron transport channels are established, Mo-O clusters can swiftly acquire e- from Fe(II), establishing the valence reduction process Mo(Ⅵ → V). The oxidation reaction cycle is established, and DBTO undergoes the same process, ultimately oxidizing to dibenzothiophene sulfone (DBTO2) for deep desulfurization. In the whole ODS reaction system, HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) not only provides an effective site for the activation of DBT, but also promotes the formation of •OH radical groups through electron transport. (8) M o V + H 2 O 2 → M o VI + ( ⋅ OH ) + ( − OH ) (9) F e II + H 2 O 2 → F e III + ( ⋅ OH ) + ( − OH ) (10) F e III + e − → F e II (11) DBT + ( ⋅ OH ) + ( − OH ) → DBTO + H 2 O (12) M o VI + F e II → e l e c t r o n t r a n s f e r M o V + F e III (13) DBTO + ( ⋅ OH ) + ( − OH ) → DBT O 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel nanoporous core-shell structured HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) catalyst with deep desulfurization capability was synthesized via a facile and controllable impregnation method. The amino-functionalized metal-organic framework, with its enormous specific surface area, provided directional anchoring sites and excellent dispersibility for HPM, thereby constructing efficient nanoscale electron transport channels. Phosphate groups modulated the acidity of the catalytic environment and maintained stability. Meanwhile, the introduction of the electron-donating amino group generated in situ low-valence metal active sites (Fe(II) and Mo(V)), facilitated the activation of hydrogen peroxide. Catalysts with suitable nanoporous window sizes were designed, which is essential for achieving efficient desulfurization. In this study, HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) achieved 99.8 % ODS performance under optimal conditions(V(ILs) = 1 mL, V(H2O2) = 0.15 mL, catalyst/model oil (0.02/5, g/mL), 50 °C), while also demonstrating excellent recyclability. Compared to individual component, the HPM@NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) exhibited a 3.43-fold enhancement in ODS performance relative to NH2 −MIL-101(Fe) and a 1.52-fold enhancement compared to HPM. This superior performance can be attributed to synergistic effects and the successful construction of fast nanoscale electron transport channels within the heterogeneous catalytic system. A dual-pathway synergistic catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed. The core-shell catalysts significantly enhance desulfurization efficiency and sustainability by optimizing metal valence states and precise anchoring functions. This promising design strategy shows great potential in the development of catalytic chemistry. coredata.dc:description: Supported metal catalysts frequently experience diminished catalytic activity, attributed to the loss of active sites and impaired electron transport efficiency during reactions. From the perspective of structure-activity relationships, developing composite multivalent metal catalysts and elucidating the key role of synergistic effects are crucial for enhancing electron transport and ultimately improving oxidative desulfurization(ODS) performance. In this study, core-shell nanostructure based on Phosphomolybdic acid(HPM) and amino-functionalized MIL-101(Fe)(NH2−MIL-101(Fe)) was successfully synthesized through a facile and controllable impregnation method. The phosphate groups in HPM not only regulate the acidity of the catalytic environment but also maintain the overall structural stability. The enhanced mobility of lattice oxygen in HPM promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies during its interaction with NH2−MIL-101(Fe). The abundance of directional anchor sites for HPM can be provided by coordination via empty orbitals in Mo-O clusters with lone pairs of electrons on the nitrogen atoms in the amino group of NH2−MIL-101(Fe). The variable valence states of Fe and Mo efficiently activate hydrogen peroxide(H2O2). Furthermore, the mass transfer can be facilitated by carefully design pore windows, which matching the size of sulfur compounds. These synergistic effects collectively achieved 99.8 % ODS performance under optimal conditions(V(Ionic liquids, ILs)=1 mL, V(H2O2)=0.15 mL, catalyst: model oil (0.02:5, g/mL), 50 °C), while also demonstrating excellent recyclability. The reaction activation energy (45.25 kJ/mol) is calculated and the dual-pathway synergistic catalytic reaction mechanism was proposed by experiment and characterization. This study provides a promising design strategy for the research of advanced functional catalysts.
